episode.title: Green Tree Financial Corporation v. Bazzle

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We'll hear argument now in Number 02-634, the Green Tree Financial Corporation versus Lynn W. Bazzle.
Mr. Phillips.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
First in Volt and then again last term in Waffle House this Court made clear that, quote, arbitration under the Federal Arbitration Act is a matter of consent, not coercion.
It is that core Federal principle that was violated by the South Carolina Supreme Court in this case.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, Mr. Phillips, now, the contract presumably can be interpreted in accordance with the law of the State with jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Oh, to be sure, Justice O'Connor, but this contract was not interpreted in accordance with the understanding of the parties, with... with respect to the parties.
Ultimately, you have to look for the parties' consent to this kind of an agreement, and what the South Carolina Supreme Court was quite clear about--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, there was no express provision in the arbitration agreement saying that you can't have class-wide arbitration.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --To be sure, there was no express provision to that effect, but if you look at the South Carolina Supreme Court's decision in this case what it says is, first, the parties were absolutely silent with respect to class arbitration.
That's not surprising.
I've never read a class arbitration clause in any contract, and I'm told that no one's ever even attempted to draft a class arbitration clause.

But second of all, the... the court went further than that and said what was going to inform its judgment about how to interpret or how to apply this particular situation, it wasn't anything with respect to the language or understanding of the parties.
What it was was, without any contractual directive whatsoever, staying it twice, the court simply coerced Green Tree to defend a class arbitration proceeding.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, but the--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --Well, how does that... how does differ from Volt, Mr. Phillips?

There, the contract didn't say anything about the court staying the arbitration, and yet we said in our opinion that that was a permissible thing for a... that once the law of California had been invoked, that was a permissible thing to be done.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: In... the difference between this case and Volt, Mr. Chief Justice, is there the parties agreed that the arbitration itself would be controlled solely by California law.
That was the consent of the parties.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, they said the place where the construction was... was taken.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Right, and that was understood by this Court, and by the lower courts as a matter of State law, to embrace California law.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But didn't... didn't the... didn't the agreement here say it would be governed by the law of South Carolina?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: The... the underlying contract is governed by South Carolina law, but the arbitration provision itself is governed exclusively by the Federal Arbitration Act.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, is your... your argument that if the South Carolina court is unreasonable in interpreting State law, then it comes up here?
I... I just don't understand how we get this... this question.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: It seems to me there are two ways you can get to this question.
In this case, there was no effort by South Carolina Supreme Court to apply South Carolina law.
What they did... they're not looking for the consent of the parties.

They're looking to coerce a result based on their view of efficiency and equity which involves the interests of completely third parties to this... to this situation, not the parties to this particular agreement.
If--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Why do you... I'm sorry, I thought you were done.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --If, in fact, South Carolina had purported... if the South Carolina Supreme Court had purported to try to interpret this agreement as in some sense reflecting a... a consent by the parties to a class-based arbitration it would be a much, much closer case.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, what--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: That's not the standard that the court applied here.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --What if the South Carolina court in a somewhat different case had said this arbitration is going to be governed by our State rules of discovery.
The parties have said nothing about it, but they just say, if you're going to be bound by the laws of South Carolina, that's what you're going to do.
Is that bad?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: No, that's not bad at all, Mr. Chief Justice.
The difference between that, of course, is that is what you expect when you... when you consent to a bilateral arbitration arrangement.

When you say, we're going to proceed to resolve this dispute in an efficient and economical fashion, you understand that that means arbitration, however the... however that gets played out and, indeed, generally speaking, you would expect that to be a question for the arbitrator, more than you might as a matter of State law.

The difference here, of course, is we're talking about making a decision that's binding, or at least purports to be binding on literally thousands of other individuals who are not parties to this agreement, and this goes--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: And who are not... and who are not objecting so far as I know.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Well--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Green Tree is the one who's objecting.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Well, we don't know whether they objected or not.
All we know is that they received notice and took no action as a consequence of it, but--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Why... please.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --If you... if you flip this case around, in this situation, where the... where the unnamed members potentially are going to receive $5,000 to $7,500 of windfall recoveries, my guess is they're not going to object, but what if the case had gone the other way.
What if the arbitrator had issued a $1 nominal damage award for each member of this class.

Does anyone seriously doubt that the next day any of those unnamed class members could show up and say, excuse me, I have a right under my contract to choose my arbitrator in an agreement between myself--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Yes.
Yes, one might doubt it if their claim was worth $2, and it would cost them more to go into court to make the objection.
The... the class action vehicle in some cases will make an action possible that wouldn't be brought before an arbitrator before.
The--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Can I... can I respond to that, Justice Ginsburg, because you see, it seems to me that that simply reflects the manifest hostility to the arbitration agreement as it's been... as it's been written by the parties here.
I mean, basically what we're talking about is, we have a dispute.
It involves what will largely be a few thousand dollars, potentially.
I mean, the entire contract here involved $15,000 of... in one case and $7,500.

You expect the disputes are going to be relatively small, and you expect that the parties are going to choose an efficient method of trying to resolve those cases and move on, and... and they waive their right to a public, or judicial review, because the theory is, win or lose, it's worth taking the risk.
When you take that kind of a situation and you convert it into a $27 million fine, nobody would agree to that ab initio.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --Do you--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --That's true.
That's true, but what's bothering me is exactly this point.
I can understand your argument to this point.

A State, I don't think could possibly, consistent with section 2, interpret the word arbitration in a contract to contain all the bells and whistles of a court proceeding, because that would transform the arbitration into a court proceeding, and therefore they would have, in this subtle way, not only have shown hostility to but destroyed the arbitration contract, but what about this one.
Is this hostile to arbitration?

I have no doubt that Green Tree wouldn't have agreed, in all likelihood, had they known what was going to happen, and to that extent it is hostile to arbitration, but the consumers on the other side might have said, oh, we rather like it, in which case from their point of view it isn't hostile to arbitration, so sort of from one side it is, and from the other side it isn't, and how do we decide whether, overall, it is or it isn't?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: It seems to me that the linchpin theory of the case ought to be the... the point I started with, Justice Breyer, which is, you look to determine whether there is the consent of the parties or whether--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: No, but what we don't know here is whether there is or there isn't.
We have silence, and like many that are silent, you have to impute an intent, and what South Carolina did is--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Well, what South Carolina did--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --is, they imputed an intent.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --they imputed an intent.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: And they did it by a rule that says that since the other parties in our minds would have jumped for joy, and you, your client would have weeped in dismay, we in that situation interpret the contract against the drafter, which happened to be your client, so they chose the other side and thereby concluded that it was not hostile to arbitration, though it wasn't in the interest of one of the parties.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, it also doesn't reflect the consent of both of the parties.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Both parties have to consent, Justice Breyer.
That's the nature of consent.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --You... you--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: You simply can't have unilateral consent.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --The reason, as I understand it... the reason, as I understand it, you say there isn't consent was the reason you gave in your answer to the Chief Justice, that, in fact, they had agreed to be bound by South Carolina law with respect to the interpretation of the contract, but not with respect to the arbitration clause itself, and my question is, how do you draw that line?
There's nothing, per se, inconsistent between applying the FAA and applying some State law.
That has to be done.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: So why do you draw--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --South Carolina Supreme Court drew that line.
The South Carolina Supreme Court specifically held that the parties agreed that the arbitration clause would be governed exclusively by the Federal Arbitration Act, and the--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --No, but I mean, you say governed exclusively by the FAA, in the sense that the FAA naturally is going to trump any inconsistency with State law, but here, there isn't a clear inconsistency with State law, and the FAA is always applied with some State law in mind.
You have to have some procedure, and so on, and... and therefore I... I don't know how you can draw this nonporous line between the FAA and arbitration on one hand and State law on the other.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Well, there are two ways to get there.
First of all, as a matter of just South Carolina law we know that South Carolina's arbitration provisions completely go by the wayside as a matter of State law.
Munoz held that several years ago.
If the FAA applies, there is no State law that is residual to it.
It is determined by the Federal Arbitration Act, which means that the arbitrator is going to make certain kinds of decisions.
But the... I think the key line here is that arbitrators are absolutely free to fashion whatever rules they think are appropriate for resolving disputes in a bilateral situation.
The question is, where does the arbitrator get the authority to reach out to literally thousands of other parties in order to resolve their rights?

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. Phillips, first, you're not... you're not urging that there's any inherent inconsistency between the arbitration and class action.
You concede in your brief, I think, that if the parties agreed, yes, you could have a class action in arbitration.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Yes, although, Justice Ginsburg, there is not a single example that I could identify of any parties ever agreeing to go into a class action through arbitration.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Have there been no class actions in... in arbitration?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: I'm sorry?

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Have there been no class actions in--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Other than this one?

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: There are in California, but that's... that's it.
California and South Carolina are the only places, and the reason is, is that what you create is this extraordinarily hideous hybrid kind of a proceeding.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Does the AAA have no rules about--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --class actions?
It's just silent--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Not as far as I know.
I mean, they didn't file a brief in this case, but as far as I know AAA doesn't have rules specifically dealing with it.
They find it to be, as I understand it, quite burdensome to try to figure out how to deal with it.
If you think about it, this... you're... you're taking a dispute that by its nature is supposed to involve a few thousand dollars, converting it into $27 million.
The costs in this case alone--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --Well, suppose--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --If the parties had chosen, say, a New York forum... I thought an arbitration agreement is supposed to be a forum for action laws.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, that's part of it.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: If they said nothing about class action and they chose New York as a forum, New York has a class action vehicle.
They could get... the plaintiffs could get a class action, is that not so?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, I mean, the difficulty with that is that there's... there's no State law in general... I mean, there are no statutes out there that provide for class actions with respect to arbitrations.
That's why this is a hostile--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But it... it... then arbitration is something other than a mere choice of forum, because--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Oh, absolutely.
The Federal Arbitration Act creates a substantive law of arbitrability.
To be sure, it incorporates and embraces decisionmaking by the arbitrator.

It recognizes some limited role in some circumstances for State law, although again South Carolina doesn't do that, but there... there is nothing that provides a mechanism for converting your ordinary bilateral--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --Can I... can I interrupt with this question, Mr. Phillips?
Supposing you had the... Green Tree had agreements with a large... large number of consumers, and suppose 15 of them filed separate arbitrations, they all went before the same arbitrator.
Could the arbitrator have entered an order saying, I think it would be efficient to have all these cases tried together, so I'm going to enter an order requiring you to do so?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --I... I think if the parties all agreed to have it resolved by the same arbitrator--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, supposing the... supposing Green Tree objects.
Could he nevertheless do it?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --No.
I think in that situation what you're then doing is depriving us of our right under those agreements to choose our own arbitrator.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Oh, but here... here the South Carolina arbitrator, which you... you certainly consented to his appointment, went ahead and did pretty much this.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Not... not as sweeping--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --This in a vengeance, I will say, Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Well, but what is your... what is your principle objection to Justice Stevens' hypothetical where the arbitrator simply says, I've got 15 of these and I'm going to just try them together?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: I... I have a substantial... substantially less of an objection to that kind of a procedure because it doesn't adjudicate unnamed parties' rights, or purport to adjudicate those rights.
At least you have a real dispute that already exists--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --which can justify in some sense consolidation.
I still think you have to respect Green Tree's right--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --But then... but you say your... your objection would have been cured if the arbitrator had written a letter to every plaintiff and gotten an... a written okay, that would have made it okay?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --No, because the... the arbitration process requires the filing of claims and going through it.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well then, what's the difference between that and my 15-individual case?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Because we don't know whether there is, in fact, a dispute between the parties in the absence of some effort by the plaintiffs to come forward.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, they know there's a common issue in all these cases... I mean, they... they all had the same legal issue involved, didn't they?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: But... but it... just because you may have a right doesn't mean you necessarily care to assert your right.

Again, it's... it's easy to look at this case and say, well, gee, there's an opportunity to pick up $5,000 in windfall, or $7,500 in windfall, but you know, an arbitrator could just as easily have rendered a decision here that said, this is a pure technicality, it's entitled to $1 in nominal damages, and the class-wide relief ought to be $1,900, and attorney's fees ought to be a third of that, which is $600--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: And... and--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --and I guarantee you they would not be willing or prepared to... I'm sorry, Justice Kennedy.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --Please, finish your answer.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: They would not be prepared to abide by that.
Every one of the unnamed members would say, I never had an opportunity to... to participate in the selection of the arbitrator who has resolved my substantial rights.
There's no basis at all to bind me under these circumstances, and I'm going to show up and make a claim.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well, the obvious solution to that would be to read into their contract the idea that they had agreed to that situation provided they're fairly represented, et cetera, and if they don't like the result, they can arbitrate that, too.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: But see, Justice Breyer, we... we keep making up more and more and more, and none of this is... is at all linked to any kind of consent among any of these parties.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: I want to ask about consent.
At what point and how did you first object to the class action?
Did... did you instruct the arbitrator that we consented to your appointment for individuals A, B, and C, but not for other--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --We... we do not consent.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: We do not consent to that.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: And when did you do that?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: We raised that as--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: After the first--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --as early and often--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --the idea of class action.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Yes, and the South Carolina Supreme Court specifically addressed the question of waiver and found that we never waived our right with respect to that.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But you did select the arbitrator.
It was your arbitrator.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: It was our arbitrator with respect to the dispute with the Bazzles and the Lackeys and the Buggses, to be sure, but we did not agree to an arbitrator to resolve any disputes involving unnamed third parties--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well, it leaves this open, and I mean, I agree with you that it is... whether you did... whether this or is not the proper interpretation of what the parties intended is certainly disputable, and if it's disputable, why shouldn't the arbitrator decide that?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --See, I don't think it is disputed what the parties... what the parties intended, Justice Breyer.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well... well, wait.
You... I'm going to hear in about 10 minutes or so a pretty good argument the other side, too--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Except that--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --so that my question is, where you have a contract that says, interpretations of the contractor should be arbitrated, and where, in fact, what we're arguing about today is how one part of the contract should be interpreted, how did we get here?
Why wasn't that referred to the arbitrator?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Because the question of whether the arbitrator has the authority to resolve the rights of unnamed third parties is not a question for the arbitrator to decide.
That's a question for the court to decide.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Because it goes--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I would have thought the meaning of a--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --It goes to the core of the arbitrator's jurisdiction and authority to decide.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --No, but wait.

There is a case, including one I just wrote, I think, for the Court which makes very clear that what you send to the arbitrator... I mean, there are dozens of cases where you have a phrase in a contract, and that's in dispute, and the parties have agreed we send disputes about the meaning of the contract to arbitration, you send that to the arbitrator.
I mean, the only things that you don't are whether there's the arbitration contract is itself valid, et cetera.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Justice Breyer, I think on the question of whether the arbitrator has jurisdiction--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --and authority to decide the rights of a party, that is a question for the court to decide--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Okay, is there any... is there any--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --not for the arbitrator.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --Is there any case you could cite... I mean, I read most of them when I... when I wrote the opinion in the Howsam case.
I don't think you can think of one.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: But Howsam dealt with the specific problem of the procedures to be followed with respect to a bilateral--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Oh, are we talking about that here?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --No, we're not talking about the procedures to be followed in a bilateral agreement.
We're talking about what you have to do--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well, I--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --to resolve the rights of third parties who are not signatories--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --Why should--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --As to the other contracts--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --the ones that get sucked into this massive litigation, it is certainly a jurisdictional issue--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: That... that's my point, Justice Scalia.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --if not as to yours.
Yours, you... you agree to the arbitrator and whatnot, but... but take... take somebody else who--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: And anything the arbitrator did to us--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --I'm sorry, I don't understand the meaning of when you say it's a jurisdictional issue, when you agree to somebody else's statement it's a jurisdictional issue.
What I have in front of me is a contract.

It says, in this phrase, disputes will be arbitrated, there is a question, what does that mean, that word arbitration in this contract, and then I know that the parties have agreed to arbitrate the meaning of the dispute, all right... of any phrase--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Right, but--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --including that one.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Right.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: So... so how did we suddenly get into court, was my question?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Because, Justice Breyer, the... the contract says that... that it binds us and you, and us and you are defined as Green Tree and the... and the specific named participants in this proceeding.
It doesn't say word one about the rights of all of the other individuals in this--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But the other individuals--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --and the South Carolina... I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --The other individuals are not here complaining.
I mean, they're probably glad they got the 7,000 bucks--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Oh, they're not here complaining today, but Mr. Chief Justice, you're going to have to resolve the question of whether or not you can interpret an arbitration agreement in a way that allows these kinds of proceedings for the... for the generality of cases, and what do we--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --If you're concerned about the third parties, how does it differ from a court-declared class action where the safeguards are the class members have notice, and there's a notice here that is clearer than most notices, and if they're... if they say that they were inadequately represented, they could collateral attack on that basis.
Why should those States' laws be any different in an arbitral forum than in a court forum?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Well, if you were going to allow a class action in an arbitral forum you would certainly want those... those protections to be built in.
My point is, is that the way you get those kinds of protections to exist in the ordinary class action is because the State coerces the litigation.

The ordinary rule is that you cannot represent third parties, and the court has identified as a matter of its power situations in which it's going to embrace that approach, but that doesn't get you past the contract problem.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But the court can't do it as it... the Federal rules have a class action provision--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --and the Federal rules can't affect substantive rights, only procedure, so the class action device, classes are certified every day in... in Federal court--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: But--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --and they're not changing the substance of any contract that they're declaring in a contract setting, a class action.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --The... the difference there, Justice Ginsburg, is that here we're talking about a situation where the full authority of the arbitrator is defined by the consent of the specific parties to the agreement, and these parties don't have the authority to bind nonparties.
The Court said just last term in Waffle House--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: They're not in court by reason of a contract.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --I... I'm sorry, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: They are not in court by reason of a contract.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: That's correct, Justice Scalia.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Here, they are before the arbitrator only by reason of a contract.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor, and... and--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But isn't the difficulty... and I... I... I'm still having trouble getting over this.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Isn't the difficulty that... one... one thing you said a second ago is... is really not accurate, I don't think.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Well, I apologize--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: They don't consent to every jot and tittle of means by which the arbitration will be conducted.

They consent in a gross kind of way to arbitration or nonarbitration, and... and that's... that's what their consent makes the difference between, but they don't consent to every consequent detail that enters into the actual conduct of the arbitration, so why should we draw the line where you want us to draw the line as opposed to drawing the line a little further and saying, if you consent to arbitration and a State says, not inconsistently with the FAA, arbitration can be done on a class basis if there are common issues and so on?
Why should we draw the line to exclude that?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Well, there are two answers to that.

The premise of it, which is that the FAA doesn't have anything to say about this, but the core principle of the FAA is that there is supposed to be consent of the parties, so we ought to be looking to the expectation of the parties to determine what rights you're going to adjudicate as a matter of arbitration.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: You're... you're saying, this is so far from anything that would have been contemplated--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --as a detail to be filled in later, and that's why you draw the line--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: That's... that is exactly right, Justice Souter, and if you look at the South Carolina Supreme Court's opinion it doesn't talk about anything that has to do with consent.
It talks about equity and fairness and judicial economy, all factors that influence the rights of third parties who have nothing to do with the arbitration agreement that's before the arbitrator.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --I thought the South Carolina Supreme Court said there's a... there's a silence in this contract and we're going to construe it against the drafter.
You concede that you could have arbitration in a class format, and so that South Carolina said it doesn't... this contract doesn't say one way or the other and we'll construe it against the drafter.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: The... but what the South Carolina Supreme Court said was, we're going to promote judicial economy and we're going to do it without a contractual directive to do so.

To be sure, the court said we... we do not find language so clear here... because you know, what they're basically worried about is, does this absolutely prohibit the possibility of class arbitration.
Is there language in there that says, under no circumstances will we ever have class arbitration.
I would have read the... this agreement to have actually said that, but they didn't say that.

What they said is, well, we think it's... we think it's ambiguous, and therefore we'll construe it against you, but all that gets you to the point is that the contract says nothing about this, and the problem with trying to square that with the FAA is that the animus for, or the... the motivation for acting under the Federal Arbitration Act is the consent of the parties, not simply can you manipulate the contract in a way that gets you to--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But it... but it is true, is it not, that everybody in the class has consented to an arbitration with Green Tree--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --No.
No.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --Not to a class action arbitration, but to an arbitration.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, has... well, has consented... yes, has signed an arbitration agreement--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But not with these arbitrators.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --But not with this arbitrator, that's correct.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But I thought that--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: We had--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --But they have consented to the--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --And we have a right in it, and it's worth pointing out we still have a right, with respect to each one of those third party claims, to have our choice of arbitrators.
We picked this guy for these three or four claims.
As Justice Kennedy observed, we went--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --But is it really reasonable to assume that if he knew he had a thousand different arbitrations coming up he'd want a thousand different arbitrators?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Sure.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: With the same issue in every case?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Sure.
Why not?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Because--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --Don't they wear... wear out after just one case, then?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, the... the point is that--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You might not want to put your company's entire future in the hands of one arbitrator.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Of a single arbitrator--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --with no right to judicial review--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Makes some sense.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Justice Stevens.

The problem is, why would we make a judgment at the outset of this process that says, we are going to enter into the most informal decisionmaking process with no right to judicial review and with $27 million at stake.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Where... where is it--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: No one would.
It would be madness.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --Where is it in the record that you first made your objection to the class action, and do you... does that objection say that we have not consented to the arbitration as to these other parties?
Is that how your objection was phrased, and where can I find it in the record?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Justice Kennedy, I'm going to have to answer that on... in the rebuttal.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: I'll give you the specific citation when I step up here.
If there are no other questions, I'll reserve the balance of my time.

section.heading: Argument of Cornelia T. L. Pillard

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Very well, Mr. Phillips.
Ms. Pillard, we'll hear from you.

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
Green Tree first protested by asking the arbitrator to decide whether the case could go forward as a class.

They did not object to his power to decide, but they asked him to decide and I... I think the relevant document is on page 15 of the joint appendix, which is Green Tree's memorandum to the arbitrator.

There is nothing in the FAA that preempts a State court or arbitrator from applying ordinary State contract law, the doctrine of construction against the drafter, to read a contract to authorize class arbitration.
As a legal matter, the consent of the parties is determined under State contract law by applying the doctrines of contract law to resolve ambiguities where they exist.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: What doctrine of state contract law led you... led to this result, the doctrine of construe the instrument against, contra proferentem against the person who drafted it?

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: That's exactly right, Justice Scalia.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Now, can... can that produce anything?
I mean, suppose one side claims the contract says nothing about it, but one side claims, you should pay all the costs of the arbitrator, all right.

Is... is a State court going to decide that question by simply saying, well, the contract says nothing about it, but to do it that way would be against the interests of the drafter, so yes, it's in the contract?

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: The--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And my next question is going to be, what if the other side comes in and says, you ought to pay me $10 million, and the other side says, gee, there's nothing in the contract about that.
[Laughter]
Can the State court say, well, it's against the... it's against the interests of the drafter so it must be there in the contract?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I mean, that seems... this seems to me just as weird--

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: --You apply--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --to... to pluck out a right to a class action for no other reason than that it is against the interests of the person who drafted the contract.
It's weird.

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: --Justice Scalia, the... the argument is that the arbitrator has the authority under State law to interpret the ambiguity in the contract, and it's not weird at all in this case, where, since 1979 in South Carolina, arbitrators have had the authority to consolidate arbitrations, and the leading cases, Champ, the case on which Green Tree relies, Episcopal Housing, which is the First Circuit case, the... the cases that look at whether this is allowed, advert to... I'm sorry, Episcopal Housing was itself a consolidation case, but the cases that allow class arbitration advert to the underlying rule in the jurisdiction--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: There's a big difference--
--What are consolidation arbitration... what do you mean by that?
You mean when the same arbitrator has more than one case involving the same issue?

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: --The same arbitrator can take different disputes under arbitration clauses and bring them together where--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: When he's been selected for the various issues.
I mean he... he's been selected in... in all of the various cases.
The parties have agreed to this arbitrator.
They just haven't agreed to have them all decided in one proceeding, is that right?

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: --That's right.
They're all... but, that's one of the versions--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But that... that's a long... that's a long way off from compelling somebody who hasn't agreed to this arbitration.

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: --It... it's not at all.
First of all, I disagree with the premise of your question, Justice Scalia, that they haven't agreed to this.

Where the contract permits it, what Green Tree and the... the class members, absent and named class members agreed to was a contract with the potential for a class proceeding, with the potential for a class proceeding.
This... under the Southland cases, since... since 20 years ago cases have been going forward--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: That begs the question.
I mean, that precisely begs the question.
I mean--

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: --They--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --that's what we're debating, whether they... whether they agreed to that or not, and to say that they agreed to it because they agreed to it doesn't get us very far.

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: --This is an FAA preemption case, but the FAA has nothing to say here.
The act doesn't say anything about class arbitration, and the FAA ousts only State law that is hostile to arbitration.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: All right, well, why isn't this hostile?
It seems to me that is the question.

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: It's not hostile--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well, wait, let me give you an example.
You would agree that the State couldn't interpret silence as follows.
The word arbitration in this contract, since it's silent, means that the arbitration will take place at the bottom of a coal mine with no air, okay.
We agree, right?

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: --Right.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: All right, and what the other side has said is, you know, in respect to one of the parties, this is the same thing.

Of course my client would never have agreed to arbitration if he knew that a class action lawyer could find a provision in the contract that nobody thinks really hurt them but, in fact, we didn't live up to, and then obtain $10 million in a judgment before an arbitrator, of which he gets three and the rest is distributed.
Now, look, that's what we were trying to get away from.
That's why we went to arbitration and not the court.

Of course we wouldn't agree to such a thing, and of course reading such a thing into the silence is the same as putting us at the bottom of that coal mine, or at least close enough so you cannot say that it is neutral as to whether or not arbitration is good or bad or likely to occur, or Volt was neutral or pro-arbitration.
This State rule is not neutral, it is hostile to it.
Now, that's basically their argument, as I understand it, and I'd like to hear the reply.

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: I think, Justice Breyer, that misapprehends what we mean by hostile to arbitration.

Hostility to arbitration refers to State rules that are suspicious of or undermine the ability of an arbitral forum to resolve a dispute, and saying that a case is going to proceed on a class basis is a far cry from saying this case is going to proceed at the bottom of a coal mine, where parties' rights would actually be... would not be able to be fulfilled.
That's the outside edge.
This Court has... has always said, well, arbitration can't go forward if the parties can't get meaningful relief, and... and I think your coal mine case would be such a case.
But what we mean by hostile to arbitration is not whether one or the other party to the arbitration wishes that they, in the end, once the dispute arises, that they weren't before an arbitrator.
No.
What we mean is, whether State law reflects a suspicion about the capacity of arbitration to resolve a dispute, and if anybody--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Could they... could they then have a State law that says, and the party that invokes the arbitration in the contract will receive from the other party a bonus of about $100,000 for having done a good thing?
See, that's equally ridiculous as to my example in the coal mine, and all I've done is make sure that the arbitration... it's not... it's not... you see, it satisfies your test.

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: --I... I don't think it does, because it's... well, because it's... it's targeted at the arbitration, and if the State had such a rule one could look at, what's the purpose, what's the legitimate purpose of that rule--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: They love arbitration.
Oh, but forget my ridiculous example.
Go ahead with your... with your... with your explanation.

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: --It seems the... well, that is... is the focus.
The focus has to be whether the State law, not looking at ex post, once the parties are... are unhappy with the broadly worded contract--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Okay, I've got that.

Then do you think... the other question that's bothering me... that was one, and there's one other, is that we have the words in the contract here, and the words are, the dispute, any claim, including what the contract means, or the validity of the arbitration clause, et cetera, shall be resolved by binding arbitration, by one arbitrator, selected by us, with consent of you, okay.

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: That's the phrase.

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Now, there obviously is a disagreement as to the meaning of that phrase.
Well, why shouldn't that be arbitrated?

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: Exactly, and it was.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: All right.
Then what we should do in this case is say, forget what the North Carolina Supreme Court says--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --South Carolina.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: South Carolina, sorry.
I got it right the first time... South Carolina Supreme Court.
Forget what they say.
The question is, what did the parties mean, and therefore send it back to the arbitrator for that determination, not influenced by the South Carolina opinion in front of us.
Now, is that the correct resolution, then?

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: No, Justice Breyer.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Because?

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: Because the arbitrator already did look at this clause and decided that the... that the language of the arbitration agreement allowed him to decide.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I thought the first case was a case where the South Carolina Supreme Court, Bazzle or one of them was... the South Carolina Supreme Court said what it meant, not the arbitrator.
The second case, which was in front of the arbitrator, was the arbitrator being influenced by what the South Carolina Supreme Court had said.

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: The... the Bazzle case did not go up to the South Carolina Supreme Court before--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Then it's the other, it's Lackey the Supreme Court--

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: --The cases came up to the Supreme Court together--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: --after both decisions were made, and as an initial matter the Bazzle case went to the trial court, which decided as an initial matter that the... in the Lackey case the... the arbitrator made the decision as an initial matter, looking at the language of the contract and determining, without any prior judicial instruction on the matter--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Not instruction, but... but was he not guided or influenced in some way by the Supreme Court decision?

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: --Green Tree tries for the first time in this Court to dispute that the arbitrator in Lackey made an independence decision--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: --that the contract authorized class arbitration.
That argument is a complete red herring.

Their own brief to the South Carolina Supreme Court repeatedly asserted that in Lackey the arbitrator, quote, took it upon himself to determine the propriety of a class-wide arbitration and certify a class.
That's at page 29 of their South Carolina Supreme Court brief.
They say again and again... their question presented refers to the arbitrator deciding the class action issue himself.
That's question presented 2--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: That was in... that was in Lackey.

In Bazzle, did the arbitrator, after the, what I'll call referral from the State trial court, did the arbitrator then say, as an... as an independent matter, I ratify, I confirm, I... I agree that the contract should be interpreted this way, or does it... or did he just say, I am following the order of the court?

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: --We don't have either precisely, but let me tell you what I think is relevant to that.
The arbitrator in Bazzle did also consider the issue.
The issue was placed squarely before the arbitrator when Green Tree moved him to decertify the class to grant that Green Tree did fight this, a--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Wait, wait, wait.
Why... why... what issue was placed before him when they moved to decertify him?

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: --They moved to decertify--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: The issue of whether he would be in... in violation of the order of the South Carolina Supreme Court?

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: --There was no order of the South Carolina Supreme Court at that time.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: There was only the order of the trial court, which read the contract to allow class arbitration.
Then it... the class was certified and sent to the arbitrator, and then the issue was before the arbitrator should be decertify the class, and Green Tree argued that... that they should.

Moreover, in Green Tree's motion to vacate the award, after the arbitrator in Bazzle made the arbitration award, they characterized the arbitrator as having made the decision that the class could proceed in arbitration.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I'm sure they did, so... but my impression is they appointed in Bazzle, the district court appointed a class, or certified it.

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: Certified a class.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: All right, it was after that that they go to the arbitrator in Lackey, and now what they're telling us is, the arbitrator in Lackey, knowing that the district court had appointed the class in Bazzle, then appointed the class in Lackey, and what they say, I take it, is well, that's not independent, he just thought that's what he's supposed to do.

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: Right, and... and I very much disagree with that characterization of the record, and I'll try to help to make it clearer.
First, as I pointed out, in their own briefs in the South Carolina Supreme Court, they characterized the Lackey arbitrator as having acted independently.
There is no... no record support for Green Tree's current assertions that the arbitrator did not make an independent decision.
There is nothing in the record that supports it, and it is not the case.
The arbitrator said that he determined that a class action should proceed based on his careful review of the broadly drafted arbitration clause prepared by Green Tree.
That's--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Is there any history, Ms. Pillard, of this in South Carolina, or is this the first time?
Have there been class proceedings before arbitrators in the past?

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: --I'm not aware that there are, Justice Ginsburg.
I'm not aware of any reported decisions on that.
There have been class arbitrations in... in the... one of the largest economies in the world for... for 20 years, and there have been a smattering of class arbitrations in other places, and I... I--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Ms. Pillard, when... when a class action is instituted, it seems to me it amounts to an interpretation not just of... of these contracts that were in front of this arbitrator, but also of the other contracts that have been brought into this arbitration, and what I find it difficult to see is how any interpretation of one of those other contracts would... would allow them to be brought into this from the standpoint not of this company... this company at least selected this arbitrator for these cases, and you could say, well, they didn't select him for the other cases, which may be a good point, but let's talk about the customers, the plaintiffs.
They didn't select this arbitrator for any case, not even... not even for their own case.

They have had foisted upon them not some Federal district judge who has, you know, the... the army behind him, but... but some arbitrator that, you know... who knows who, that they... they never selected at all.
How can you possibly draw them into this... how can you possibly say that that contract is reasonably interpreted to allow them to be brought into this... into this arbitration?

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: --I have two answers to that, Justice Scalia.

First, there's no question that if, under a contract that had a forum selection clause that said, any disputes under this contract will be resolved in a forum chosen by us with the consent of you, and a plaintiff chose a forum and filed a class action and offered opt-out rights to every absent class member who wanted to opt out, and those absent class members were bound by the same contract, their right to consent to the forum would be protected.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But that's deceptive.
They... they are summoned in by the power of the Government, not by... not by their... their contractual commitment to be summoned in.

Even if there were no contract they could be made part of a class action, so to say that you can do it when the Government is coercing it, and therefore it's a perfectly reasonable interpretation of a contract, doesn't make sense to me.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Here, the only basis for getting... for getting these plaintiffs into this court, or into this arbitral court is their voluntary agreement, and their voluntary agreement gave them the right to select an arbitrator, and they have been deprived of that right entirely.

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: --I agree with you, Justice Scalia, up to your last sentence.
They have not been deprived of that right.

It is exactly true that the authority of the arbitrator over the absent class members derives from contract, and every single absent class member was a... a signatory to the... to the same arbitration clause.
They were all governed by the same clause, and once--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But... but Green Tree didn't appoint the arbitrator for that purpose.
Green Tree appointed the arbitrator for X, Y, and Z.

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: --Green Tree wrote a clause that... it swept everything within it.
They said, we trust everything to the arbitrator.
This clause is extremely broad.
Once they did that... they drafted a clause which the arbitrator and every South Carolina judge to look at it believed was susceptible of a reading that had authorized class action.
In that case, you read this contract as if it had provided for class arbitration, and when they select--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Wait, wait--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --Could the... could the arbitrator have said, I'm... I'm going to include in... in this class some people who don't have an arbitration contract at all?

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: --I would think not, no, and indeed, those people were excluded in this case.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: And... and why is that?

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: Because they have--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Because the... Green Tree did not consent to that.

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: --Because they have no... the arbitrator has no authority over them, because neither they nor Green Tree consented to that, but by hypothesis, if you had a clause--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: The hypothesis is, the consent must be bilateral, and here it wasn't.

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: --Oh, I disagree.
The consent was bilateral.

Green Tree chose an arbitrator, and when it chose an arbitrator for a case under a contract broad enough to authorize class action, legally it has chosen an arbitrator with the possibility that the class could proceed.
Indeed, when they chose--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: All right, but what--

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: --the arbitrator, the case had already been filed as a class action.
It was... they were on notice--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: --of the possibility that this issue would be litigated on a class basis.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, they were on notice that somebody wanted a class action, but it seems to me, number 1, they were not on notice that South Carolina law would provide a... a class arbitration because, as you said, it hadn't occurred before, and the only thing that they definitely consented to was an arbitrator for this case, and in a situation in which there was no existing State law that put them on notice that they were in jeopardy of this result, they're saying there are some things we... I think they're saying there are some things we... we agree that have to be filled in later about the terms of the arbitration.

But with no history to indicate that the request for class... or class treatment would be granted and would be possible under South Carolina law, we surely did not consent, we certainly did not take the risk that we consented, that we were consenting to arbitration for all of these other people, and if you doubt that, Mr. Phillips says, just step back and... and bear this in mind.
Without judicial review, would we have rolled the dice for $27 million on one arbitrator?
What is... what is your answer to that, that it, in effect, it is just too implausible to draw this conclusion out of the limited consent that they gave?

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: I have several answers to that, Justice Souter.

First of all, this Court has never said that a case with a large amount of money at stake, indeed in Mitsubishi Motors with antitrust cases, in McMahon with RICOs... RICO and securities cases, large amounts of money at stake, arbitration is permitted.
They--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Oh, no question about it.
It's a question of what they plausibly consented to.

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: --Right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That's the point of his argument.

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: Right.
They were... they were on notice.

If they had good lawyers doing this, they would have a long time before 1998 put in the simple one phrase that they put into their contract as of 1998 which says, nobody who signs this can be a class member or a class representative.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, if they had been in California they would have done that, but were... were, you know, were they on notice that they had better guard against that jeopardy in South Carolina?

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: Yes.

I think in... in particular, the Episcopal Housing case put them on notice as of 1979 there were consolidations being permitted, and the courts who were looking at the class question, the Champ court--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Consolidations aren't class actions.
I mean, those are quite different.

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: --I agree with you, Justice Scalia, but the fact of the matter is, the courts that have decided whether or not to authorize class arbitration in an appropriate case have looked as an analogy to the consolidation precedent, so you have a jurisdiction in which there is consolidation precedent, and parties, when they agree to contracts in ambiguous terms, agree to submit to the natural evolution of State law, and that is... that does on occasion present risks.
That does present risks, but they chose both to draft a clause very broadly and to submit everything to the arbitrator.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, they're saying this isn't natural evolution, this is creationism, and--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: [Laughter]

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --don't... don't they have a... don't they have a point that there is a distinction when the difference gets to be that great?

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: No, and I... and I certainly don't think that is a preemption question for this Court.
I certainly don't think so.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: No, no, but it says the terms have to be... I mean, it doesn't... it says in the statute you have to enforce the arbitration that they wrote, and here... now, it is... this point is bothering me, because I'm not sure what your answer to this was.
I do see the phrase, shall be resolved by binding arbitration, by one arbitrator selected by us, with consent of you.
Now, the opt-out can be, consent of you.
I get that.
If they don't opt out, they consent, but what about the phrase, by one arbitrator selected by us?

We've come around, we've been talking about that nonstop, but I... I don't have a clear answer to that, because what seems absolutely clear in the case of Justice Scalia and me, and he's never been in this courtroom, or in the arbitrator room or anywhere, you know, I didn't select that arbitrator.
I selected you for a different case.
Now... now, how do we... how do we square that with the words, an arbitrator selected by me, if I'm Green Tree?

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: Because... two reasons.
One is that this was filed as a class action, so when they selected the arbitrator they were on notice that at least the plaintiffs were trying to do this.
The second--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: So if they said right at that point we don't want this as a class action, then they win?

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: --No.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: No, okay.

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: The second answer is that the contract was written in such a way as to be susceptible of permitting class arbitration, so when they select an arbitrator under this contract, they take into account, this could be an arbitrator that could award punitive damages.
This could be an arbitrator that could proceed on a class basis.
This could be an arbitrator who could order--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: All right, I see, but--

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: --broad discovery.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --If they had had a--

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: This could be an arbitrator who could do any of the things the contract permits.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --If they had had enough foresight, could they have told the arbitrator, we are selecting you, but for this suit only.
You may not have a class action.
We are not consenting.
Could they have said that up front?

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: I don't think so.

I don't think so, because the... the language of the contract and the authority that they have given to arbitrators is determined from the contract language, not from the parties' choices at the threshold where a particular dispute has already arisen.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: I... I notice the... none... none of your answers to these questions, including... you had several answers for Justice Souter.
None of your answers said, well, you know, that's a very interesting theory, Mr. Justice, but this is a State law matter, it's not for you.
I... I haven't heard that.

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: Well, I... I intended to give... to give that answer when I said this is not a preemption question.
It is not an FAA question.

It is a State law question, and I think that's exactly right, Justice Kennedy, the narrow scope of FAA preemption focuses on whether State law is hostile to the arbitration forum, to the choice of arbitral forum to resolve ambiguities like these.
There is--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Suppose a... suppose the State law said, not only do we interpret silence to mean you can have it in a class format, but that if any arbitration clause... any arbitration contract excludes class action we will hold that against our public policy and unenforceable?

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: --One would have to look at the reasoning of the State court in so holding.
If the reasoning was hostility to arbitration, trying to trade it up--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Well, the... the Supreme Court would explain, we love arbitration, that's why we're not going to let anybody make it a smaller arbitration, so that's... so we're not being hostile to arbitration.

turn.speaker: cornelia_t_l_pillard
turn.label: Ms. Cornelia T. L. Pillard
turn.text: --That is, as the South Carolina Supreme Court made clear, not the issue in this case.
If it were an application of general contract principles of unconscionability in a particular case with no suspicion of arbitration as such, then I think a State could do that under State law.

If the State had a general law that applied to litigation and arbitration against class action waivers, or against waivers of class actions in adhesive contracts that applied to both fora, to the litigation and to the arbitration, I think under that circumstance also it would not be hostile to arbitration for the State law to override the parties' choice--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: What's your authority that... that it has to be... you... you seem to... to be positing some kind of a... of an intent requirement on the part of the State.
It has to have it in for arbitration.
